results.title: ‘Tár’ Review: A Maestro Faces the Music
results.abstract: Cate Blanchett stars as a world-famous conductor heading for a fall in Todd Field’s chilly, timely backstage drama.

results.title: ‘Triangle of Sadness’ Review: Don’t Worry, Be Happy
results.abstract: Ruben Ostlund won the top prize at Cannes for this preening, obvious satire of contemporary hypocrisy.

results.title: ‘Amsterdam’ Review: A Madcap Mystery With Many Whirring Parts
results.abstract: Christian Bale, Margot Robbie and John David Washington lead a crowded cast of zanies in David O. Russell’s latest screwball outing.

multimedia.caption: In “Amsterdam,” Christian Bale, Margot Robbie and John David Washington play three American comrades who met in Europe during World War I.

results.title: ‘Last Flight Home’ Review: An Intimate Memorial
results.abstract: The director Ondi Timoner creates an account of her father’s final days.

results.title: A Father Chose to End His Life at 92. His Daughter Hit Record.
results.abstract: To cope with the impending loss of the family patriarch, who decided on medically assisted suicide, Ondi Timoner did what she knows best: She made a movie.

multimedia.caption: Ondi Timoner filmed her father’s last days. “I wanted to bottle him up,” she said. “I was terrified to not hear his voice again.”
multimedia.copyright: Brad Torchia for The New York Times

results.title: Spooky Season Has Arrived in New York. Here’s What’s on Our List.
results.abstract: Haunt the streets at Halloween parades. Dance at a “Zombie Prom.” Or find your way through a corn maze. We’ve got you covered on how to celebrate.

multimedia.caption: The Village Halloween Parade last year. The parade returns on Halloween Day with hundreds of puppeteers, dancers, artists and musicians marching in Greenwich Village.

results.title: Review: In ‘To Leslie,’ an Unflinching Working-Class Elegy
results.abstract: The small-budget indie is a complex portrait of the ways that trauma and addiction haunt an alcoholic mother, and her family, in the South.

results.title: An Empress Ahead of Her Time Is Having a Pop Culture Moment
results.abstract: A Netflix series and a new movie explore the life of Elisabeth, the 19th-century Empress of Austria who had a tattoo, worked out daily and wanted more from life than just producing heirs.

results.title: ‘Battleground’ Review: A Look at the Anti-Abortion Movement
results.abstract: Months after Roe v. Wade was overturned, this documentary provides, if nothing else, a glimpse into the minds of the mobilized minority leading the anti-abortion charge.

results.title: Kitten Natividad, Movie Star in Russ Meyer’s Bawdy World, Dies at 74
results.abstract: She was top-billed in his final feature, “Beneath the Valley of the Ultra-Vixens.” She was also his paramour and, he said, his favorite leading lady.

results.title: Angelina Jolie Details Abuse Allegations Against Brad Pitt in Countersuit
results.abstract: In court papers related to a legal battle over a French winery they once owned together, she claims that he was abusive to her and their children during a 2016 plane ride.

results.title: The ’90s Cartoon That Mattered? ‘Beavis and Butt-Head.’ (Fight Me.)

results.title: Will Smith Film ‘Emancipation’ Will Be Released in December
results.abstract: Apple said the movie, Mr. Smith’s first since his infamous slap at the Oscars, will be in theaters on Dec. 2 and begin streaming on Dec. 9.

multimedia.caption: There had been questions about whether Apple would release “Emancipation” this year or delay it until 2023.

results.title: Sacheen Littlefeather, Activist Who Rejected Brando’s Oscar, Dies at 75
results.abstract: The actress was booed at the Academy Awards in 1973 after she refused the best actor award on Marlon Brando’s behalf in protest of Hollywood’s depictions of Native Americans.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Ms. Littlefeather with the speech she began delivering but never finished at the Oscars ceremony in 1973. She and Mr. Brando had become friends through her neighbor the director Francis Ford Coppola.

results.title: ‘Bros’ Fails at the Box Office, as ‘Smile’ Arrives at No. 1
results.abstract: Promoted as the first gay romantic comedy from a major studio, “Bros” sold $4.8 million in tickets, about 40 percent less than expected.

multimedia.caption: Luke Macfarlane and Billy Eichner in “Bros,” which was embraced by critics but arrived in fourth place at the box office.
